column2: The Shrines
The great shrines of the Lord are scattered throughout the islands, and you can visit a shrine if the province on which it is built is under your control.\n\n Which one do you wish to travel to?
The Temple of the One-Toothed
A Grand Temple

Upon nearing the town where the temple is located, your attendants and guards part with you, as you must complete the final leg of your journey on your own. You begin walking the long road to the temple of Ekadanta, or the One-Toothed, a manifestation of the Lord.

 In the middle of your journey, you see various stalls selling religious paraphernalia to offer to the diety. Tired from the constant walking, you stop at one of these shops, striking up idle conversation with the shopkeeper.

Your eyes fall on a basket of bright blue flowers of a rare variety, used for ritual purposes.
I shall buy some to offer to the Lord
There is no need for such things
Arrival at the Temple

You have finally reached the temple. Among the throng of devotees, a priest recognizes you and leads you through the crowd and into the inner sanctum of the temple.\n\n The priest points to the far corner of the chamber. Turning to look, you see the statue of the One-Toothed. You have heard descriptions of it before, but you are still started by its appearance. Its form was as if parts from various creatures were combined into one, and it had a head like an elephant of Sol. You prostrate yourself before this manifestation of the Lord, and resolve to spend the following days in its worship.
Iishvar is second to none!
Time to Depart

After spending a few days in the temple, you decide to return. Prostrating yourself before the One-Toothed Lord one last time, you then hand a basket of ritual offerings to the priest nearby, who recites a prayer before placing the basket at the statue's feet.\n\n Then, all the priests begin chanting a final prayer of thanks, and you repeat after them. You turn to leave the temple, in order to attend to more secular matters.
I shall remember this visit
Andavan's High Abode
Andavan's Hill

Upon nearing your destination, your attendants and guards part with you, as you must complete the final leg of your journey on your own. You look towards the hill before you, on top of which lies the Shrine of Andavan, a manifestation of the Lord.\n\n Several hours pass as you inch closer to the summit, stopping intermittently to rest. Eventually, you reach a place where you have the choice of taking the regular route, or a shortcut, although the latter route is quite difficult.
I'll take the regular route
Speed is of essence
The Abode

As you ascend the steps leading up to the shrine's entrance, you catch a glimpse of the statue of the god Andavan. It towers over you, almost twice your height. You watch on as the priests place several offerings in front of him.\n\n Soon, the priests direct you to your quarters, where you will spend the next few days in quiet prayer and contemplation.
Glory to the Lord!
Time to Depart

Having ended your visit, you place offerings of food in front of Andavan while the priests chant prayers.

 You then make a donation to the shrine, and walk towards the gates. You hesitate for a moment, muttering a small prayer before leaving.

 The journey down the hill is uneventful, but the memories of your visit linger in your thoughts still.
Farewell, O Iishvar
The Shrine at Naaraayan
The Journey

Shielding your eyes from the harsh sun of the Naaraayan system, you look through the windshield at the empty stretch of land as you drive towards your destination on a utility vehicle. You unfurl your map and look dejectedly at it, as you realize you still have a long journey ahead of you.\n\n After about a day's worth of travel, you spot a convoy heading along the same path. Upon further investigation, you discover that their destination is close to Naaraayan's shrine. You calculate that you have enough fuel to make it to the shrine and back, but you also have the option of joining the convoy.
If I drive quickly, I can make it in a few days
Going with the convoy would be safer
An Unexpected Detour

It seems that in your rush to reach the shrine of Naaraayan, you have managed to get lost among the winding paths of the region. After hours of trying to find your way back to the main path, you exit your vehicle and set up camp for the night. The next morning, as you scout the surrounding plains, you spot a potential route. You set out immediately, and soon manage to spot a marker pointing the way to the system of caves where the shrine is located.
The Lord would not lead me astray
The Convoy

Staring intently at your map, you estimate that you are merely a few days away from your destination. The vehicles in the convoy began to stop near a refueling station. You were so engrossed in the map that you didn't notice that the sky had darkened already.\n\nRefueling would take till morning, but you don't feel particularly sleepy. You disembark and walk towards the various camps set up by travellers. You see a group of merchants absorbed in a board game, while other travellers exchanging stories and idle banter. One of them recognizes you, and beckons you to join them in conversation.
No harm in a little chat
I'm not in the mood for idle talk
That board game seems fun
The Patron of Naaraayan

At last, you spot the sacred cave where the shrine is built. You gesture at your companions from the convoy who chose to tag along, motioning for them to stop, while you step into the cave.\n\n Inside, you see various statues made of marble, whose paint has presumably faded over time, with the largest one of all being at the far end of the complex. It is Naaraayan, a manifestation of the Lord, after whom the star is named. You bow your head in reverence, and contemplate him in prayer for a a long time. Then, you say a final farewell, and leave the cave. Your companions pay their respects to Naaraayan from outside, and then you begin to return.
I thank the Lord of All
On second thought, I would rather not
As you have made several pilgrimages to holy sites, you are now known as a pilgrim.
Very Well
Owing to your current situation, you were forced to cancel your pillgrimage.
Unfortunate

While a great many pilgrims travel to [This.GetName] periodically, in the last few months the number of pilgrims has increased dramatically. The local infrastructure is proving incapable of handling them, and government officials have asked you to help finance a temporary expansion to meet the travellers' needs.

Unfortunate
Arrest that scholar!
Impious?! Me?!!

These activities primarily consist of independent action by charismatic preachers who recite tales from the scripture and awe the populace with acts of piety and austerity. Increasingly large amounts of people are being swayed to the Eternal Way, and adherents may soon become the majority within the system.

Perhaps there is truth in the Eternal Way

column6: Se presenta ante mí un[new_commander.GetXA] [new_commander.GetManWoman] inmens[new_commander.GetOA] con una gran reputación como comandante. Tras ver cómo trata con mis hombres, es fácil ver que sabe lo que hace.

column2: You'll fit right in!
column3: Je suis sûr[Root.Get_E] que vous serez à la hauteur !
column4: Ich bin mir sicher, dass ihr hier rein passt.
column6: ¡Seguro que encajarás!

column2: I've got just the job for you.
column3: J'ai le travail parfait pour vous !
column4: Ich habe genau den richtigen Job für euch!
column6: ¡Tengo el trabajo perfecto para ti!

column2: Actually, I do not think we need another commander.
column3: En fait, je pense que nous n'avons pas besoin d'un autre commandant.
column4: Eigentlich brauchen wir momentan keinen weiteren Kommandanten.
column6: En realidad, creo que no necesito otro comandante.

column2: A captain of a fleet of hyperspace tunnelers appears at my court, trying to sell his services in the upcoming wars. Some of my commanders question the need for these ships, but surely I could find a use for them.
column3: Le capitaine d'une petite flotte de navires est venu à ma cour et essaye de vendre ses services pour les guerres à venir. Certains de mes commandants remettent en question le besoin de navires, mais je pourrais certainement trouver comment les utiliser.
column4: Der Kapitän einer kleinen Flotte von Schiffen ist an meinem Hof erschienen und versucht seine Dienste für den kommenden Krieg zu verkaufen. Einige meiner Kommandanten bezweifeln die Notwendigkeit von Schiffen, aber ich könnte sicherlich einen Nutzen für sie finden.
column6: Aparece en mi corte el capitán de una pequeña flota, tratando de vender sus servicios en las guerras que están por venir. Algunos de mis comandantes cuestionan la necesidad de barcos, pero seguro que puedo encontrarles un uso.

column2: I will happily take you up on the offer.
column3: Je serai ravi[Root.Get_E] de vous avoir à mon service.
column4: Ich nehme das Angebot gerne an.
column6: Será un placer tomarte la palabra.

column2: You wouldn't happen to know any more captains, would you?
column3: Vous ne connaîtriez pas d'autres capitaines ?
column4: Ihr kennt nicht zufällig noch andere Kapitäne!?
column6: No conocerás más capitanes, ¿verdad?

column2: We aren't going to need those anytime soon.
column3: Nous n'avons pas besoin de navires pour combattre dans les terres !
column4: Wir brauchen keine Schiffe, um an Land zu kämpfen!
column6: ¡No necesitamos barcos para luchar en tierra!

column2: A year and a half has passed since I started my preparations for the Dharmayuddh, and I am sure that whoever wanted to take part in the war would have arrived by now. Now all that remains is to find a place to point my newfound troops towards. If I don't declare war within half a year, my allied troops might lose enthusiasm for the war altogether.
column3: Un an s'est écoulé depuis que j'ai commencé mes préparatifs pour la reconquête de la péninsule ibérique et je suis sûr[Root.Get_E] que ceux qui veulent prendre part à la reconquête ont eu assez de temps pour se manifester. Il ne reste plus qu'à trouver un endroit vers lequel orienter mes nouveaux alliés.
column4: Ein Jahr ist vergangen, seit ich mit den Vorbereitungen zur Rückeroberung von Iberien begonnen habe und ich bin mir sicher, dass jeder, der daran teilnehmen möchte, angekommen ist. Jetzt bleibt nur noch einen Ort zu finden, auf den ich meine neuen Verbündeten richten kann.
column6: Ya ha pasado un año desde que comencé los preparativos para la reconquista de la península ibérica. Estoy segur[Root.GetOA] de que ya han llegado todos los que querían participar en la Reconquista. Ahora solo resta encontrar el lugar hacia el que apuntar mis nuevos aliados.

column2: Now to find a fitting target.
column3: Maintenant, trouvons une cible adéquate.
column4: Finden wir ein passendes Ziel...
column6: Debo encontrar un objetivo adecuado.

column2: Victory

[Root.GetTitledFirstName] has won the Dharmayuddh against an adharmic ruler. The enemy's realm is in ruins, and the piety of the holy warrior can no longer be questioned. It is a joyful day for the faithful.
column3: J'ai attendu trop longtemps, semble-t-il, car mes hommes et toute ma préparation commencent à se disperser. Ils ont perdu confiance dans mes projets lorsque je n'avais pas déclenché de guerre pour l'Ibérie.
column4: Es scheint, dass ich zu lange. Meine Männer und all meine Vorbereitungen fallen langsam auseinander. Es scheint, dass die Menschen den Glauben an meine Pläne verloren haben, als ich den Krieg um Iberien nicht begonnen habe.
column6: Parece que he esperado demasiado y mis hombres y preparativos se vinien abajo. Parece que el no empezar una guerra por la península ibérica hizo que la gente perdiera la fe en mis planes.

column2: It is the will of the Lord
column3: Enfer et damnation !
column4: Verdammt!
column6: ¡Maldición!

column2: Defeat
